name: Coasts
tagline: Audubon's Coasts initiative focuses on the most threatened and iconic bird species that rely on coastal habitats—estuaries, islands, beaches, and the marine environment—throughout the hemisphere.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: Protecting and restoring coastlines will strengthen populations of shorebirds while preserving the places they need to survive throughout their lives. The work needed to accomplish this goal will also protect coastal communities against the threat of sea-level rise due to a changing climate.  By focusing on the biggest threats to 16 flagship bird species and the places they depend on, we will maximize our conservation impact and help build resilient coastlines. Those 16 flagship species represent at least 375 others as well as the ecosystems upon which they depend.

list: Increase or stabilize the populations of 20 flagship bird species by reducing threats in 4 priority landscapes
Increase the acreage of working lands in bird-friendly management programs to 500,000 acres per year.

Audubon will continue its leadership role with 11 states, multiple federal agencies, and thousands of private-sector stakeholders to implement Greater Sage-Grouse recovery plans. These plans will now cover 67,000,000 acres, and if successfully implemented, ultimately mean protecting more than 350 additional species.

Increase the amount of public and private funding available to private landowners to adopt bird-friendly land management practices by 10 percent. (In a new Farm Bill alone, this could be as much as $300 million annually.)
Through robust outreach engage 10,000 land managers in bird-friendly land management practices.
